title: What is the Real Meaning of Alchemy and its Relationship with Initiatic Science?
first_phrase: In the previous text, the author discussed the limits of bridging the gap between alchemy and chemistry, and the loss of the traditional scientific understanding of alchemy. In this concluding section, the author acknowledges that alchemy is now often interpreted solely in moral, ideal, and even psychoanalytic terms. However, the author warns against reducing alchemy to mere symbolism, as this interpretation fails to capture its essential iniziatic teaching that combines real and symbolic aspects. The author argues that at its highest level, iniziatic teachings transcend any specific application, and have a metaphysical and formless character.

last_phrase: In conclusion, an initiatic teaching has both a real and symbolic aspect and requires a synthesis of various planes of knowledge to be realized. The interpretation of alchemy solely as a transcription of spiritual doctrines disregards its physical application, which can lead to a special art of identifying the forces behind chemical phenomena. By understanding and applying this knowledge, one can unlock the mysteries of the physical world and beyond.
